reasoning: The critique targets Section 2.5’s psychological support for “eutopia is harder than it seems,” especially the hedonic-treadmill/adapted-preferences move used to argue that inhabitants’ reported satisfaction is weak evidence of high value. This is not a load-bearing premise for the paper’s main case (which relies much more on moral-pluralism-driven ‘single-flaw’ catastrophes, multiplicative-factor models, and the later ‘fussy vs easygoing’ value-function analysis), so centrality is low-to-moderate. As an objection, it has some force: it correctly identifies a potential underdetermination/‘ratchet’ structure if the authors treated any happiness report as dismissible, and it usefully flags a paternalism/coercion hazard. But it overstates how much the paper commits to unfalsifiability (the paper itself notes the treadmill analogy may mislead and does not make the thesis hinge on it), and it relies on contestable empirical claims about the stability of drives in a future with extreme preference engineering. Relevance is moderate because it engages an argumentative step in a Tier-2-ish Forethought thesis (no-easy-eutopia / value fragility) and highlights a downstream governance/lock-in failure mode (paternalistic ‘flourishing optimization’), though it does not engage the core technical/moral-uncertainty machinery where Forethought’s central cruxes lie.
title: The hedonic-treadmill argument is an unfalsifiable ratchet
